I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund was established under 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in June 2006, with a contribution of $20 million from the 
Government of the Republic of Korea. The fund aims to contribute to poverty reduction and 
foster the economic and social development process in ADB's developing member countries 
(DMCs) by supporting technical assistance (TA) projects that promote and utilize information 
and communication technology (ICT), and help facilitate the creation and sharing of information 
and knowledge.1 These activities are supported through two programs: (i) the e-Asia program 
and (ii) the knowledge partnership program.  
 
2.  High-level  consultations  are  held  annually  between  the  government  and  ADB  for 
stocktaking and defining the future directions of the government’s partnership with ADB. At the 
high-level consultation on 20–21 September 2012, the government requested a midterm review 
of the fund operations since its establishment. The review will be carried out with TA support 
and will be financed by the government through the fund. 
 
3.  Direct consultations with ADB’s regional departments will be conducted to identify DMCs 
that  will  be  included  as  case  study  countries  during  TA  implementation.  The  government 
confirmed the TA concept through a funding approval letter dated 5 June 2013. The Ministry of 
Strategy and Finance concurred on the impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, 
cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference for the TA. The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Since its initial contribution of $20.00 million to the fund, the government has made 
additional contributions: $6.37 million in November 2010, $6.00 million in September 2011, and 
$7.85  million  in  November  2012.  The  subsequent  contributions  suggest  there  is  growing 
demand for the fund, increasing awareness from DMCs and ADB staff, and a continuing interest 
to support the promotion of ICT and enrichment of knowledge for development.  
 
5.  As the fund gains more visibility, it is timely and imperative to review the midterm fund 
operations to assess the fund’s responsiveness. Based on experiences from the initial six years 
of Fund operation, eligibility criteria for the fund will be sharpened, and fund administration 
procedures will be streamlined. This will improve the performance of TA projects supported by 
the fund and the effectiveness of fund operations. 
 
6.  In addition to the midterm review, the TA will explore potential support areas to maximize 
the fund’s development effectiveness through more systematic and demand-based interventions 
in DMCs. Considering the increasing demand for ICT from DMCs and the limited resources of 
the TA, priority will be given to ICT that the e-Asia program supports. Therefore, the TA will 
include  two  components:  (i)  the  midterm  evaluation  of  fund  management  and  operational 
performance, and (ii) the review and identification of potential areas of intervention through the 
fund.

7.  ADB  recognizes  the  importance  of  ICT  for  development  (ICTD)  in  its  ICT  strategy 
approved  in  2003  and  Strategy  2020.3 The  ADB  paper  Asia:  The  Road  to  Becoming  a 
Knowledge Economy also highlighted the importance of ICT as one of the pillars for knowledge-
based economies.4 Inclusion of the potential fund support projects into country partnership 
strategy and/or country operations business plan could help align fund objectives with overall 
ADB strategies.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact will be improved effectiveness in the economic and social development of 
DMCs.  The  outcome  will  be  improved  effectiveness  of  fund  operations  and  enhanced 
knowledge partnership with the Republic of Korea. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will have three outputs: (i) the midterm evaluation report on fund operations, 
(ii) the ICTD strategy report for the e-Asia program, and (iii) the knowledge sharing of DMCs’ 
ICTD initiatives as part of the e-Asia program. 
(i)  Output 1. The midterm evaluation of fund operations will combine a desk review 
of case studies from TA projects financed by the fund. It will also include field 
missions to selected DMCs.  
(ii)  Output  2. ADB’s ICTD strategy report will be formulated for selected DMCs 
through two steps: (a) an ICTD readiness analysis will be conducted from a 
sector  perspective  covering  key  sectors  including  ICT,  infrastructure,  public 
sector management, agriculture, finance, health, and education; and (b) an ICTD 
readiness analysis for key sectors will be integrated into the ICTD strategy report 
for  target  DMCs.  Output  2  will  complement  output  1  by  strengthening  the 
strategic focus of TA fund proposals in line with the DMCs’ own ICTD policies 
and strategies. 
(iii)  Output 3. In line with output 2, at least two regional knowledge sharing forums 
on ICTD will be organized in collaboration with the government and international 
organizations such as the International Telecommunication Union (ITU). At one 
forum, participating DMCs for output 2 will share their ICTD experiences, ICTD 
readiness, and discuss their ICTD policies and strategies; the second forum will 
be  integrated  with  ADB’s  ICT  for  Development  Forum  2014  to  discuss 
approaches to address development issues through the adoption of ICT, with 
participants from ADB, DMCs, donor agencies, development partners, and the 
private sector.  
 
10.  Internal links. Given the limited TA resources and the crosscutting nature of ICT as an 
enabler  to  sector  development,  the  TA  will  selectively  target  priority  areas  including  ICT 
infrastructure, e-governance, education, finance, health, and agriculture. The TA will also target 
one or two DMCs from each region; these will be identified in consultation with ADB regional 
departments and through a fact-finding mission, if necessary. The ICT subgroup under the

11.  External  partnerships.  Throughout  the  TA  implementation,  collaboration  with 
international development partners (such as ITU), the National Information Society Agency (of 
the Republic of Korea), and private sector partners will be explored as necessary. In particular, 
one of the regional forums will be jointly organized with ITU in line with its fifth Connect Asia-

forum will be formally announced at the summit. The summit will be a good opportunity to 
discuss knowledge partnerships on ICTD in Asia and the Pacific in a more action-oriented way 
rather than a symbolic declaration. 
 
12.  Output 1 will require strong support from key stakeholders in projects financed by the 
fund. However, the difficulty in finding these stakeholders could be a potential risk, which will be 
mitigated through collaboration with ADB’s resident missions in the participating DMCs. For 
output  2,  government  agencies  of  participating  DMCs  will  need  to  be  involved  actively  to 
develop the ICTD strategy report. The risk of supply-driven TA will be mitigated through the 
systematic engagement of operations departments by utilizing the ICT subgroup and a project 
advisory committee as communication channels.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Republic  of  Korea  e-Asia  and  Knowledge  Partnership  Fund  and  administered  by  ADB. 
Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  cost  estimates  and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  ADB will be the executing agency, and RSDD will implement the TA in collaboration with 
government agencies such as the National Information Society Agency.6 Since the fund is 
intended to support ADB operations through TA financing, it is critical for the TA to have a 
systematic  communication  and  collaboration  channel  with  ADB’s  operations  departments. 
Within ADB, a project advisory committee will be established to provide direction and supervise 
project implementation; the committee will be comprised of focal ICT officers from regional 
departments, the Private Sector Operations Department, resident missions, and coordinators 
from RSDD and the Office of Information Systems and Technology. Collaboration with ITU and

15.  The TA will be implemented over 18 months, commencing in July 2013. Its completion 
date is expected to be in December 2014. It will provide 14.5 person-months of international 
consultants and 28 person-months of national consultants. A mixture of consulting firms and 
individual consultants will be engaged following (i) the quality- and cost-based selection method 
(80:20) and (ii) simplified technical proposals by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the 
Use  of  Consultants  (2013,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  Individual  consultants  will  be 
engaged for output 1 (midterm evaluation report on the fund) because evaluating trust fund 
operations is not a common expertise. A consulting firm will be engaged for output 2 (ICTD 
strategy report for the e-Asia program); however, individual consultants may be considered if no 
consulting firm qualifies because of the broad areas of expertise required. The outline terms of 
reference for consultants is in Appendix 3. 
 
16.  The progress of the TA will be evaluated against performance targets and indicators 
defined in Appendix 1. The TA will include a joint regional forum with ITU in Bangkok and a final 
conference in Manila. A series of country workshops may be held in collaboration with the case 
study DMCs. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated to the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to be financed on a 
grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund for the Midterm 
Review of the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund, and hereby reports 
this action to the Board.

3  OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A  total  of  42.5  person-months  of  national  (28  person-months)  and  international 
(14.5 person-months)  consulting  services  will  be  required  to  ensure  that  the  technical 
assistance (TA) is effectively managed and the intended outcome is achieved. Consultants will 
be recruited in accordance with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
A.  Scope of Work 
 
2.  The TA will comprise two parts. Part 1 will examine and assess the management and 
operational performance of the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund 
through business processes stipulated in the Board paper.1 Part 2 will review and identify 
potential areas of intervention to maximize the development effectiveness particularly for the e-
Asia program. For part 1, the methodology will combine a desk review of case studies of 
selected TA projects financed by the fund. It will also include field missions to the TA target 
countries  as  identified  through  consultation  with  ADB’s  regional  departments.  Part  2  will 
comprise  two  components:  (i) information  and  communication  technology  for  development 
(ICTD)  analysis  on  key  sectors  including  information  and  communication  technology  (ICT) 
infrastructure, public sector management, agriculture, finance, health, and education; and (ii) 
integrating the sector analyses for selected developing member countries (DMCs). 
 
B.  Midterm Evaluation Report 
 
3.  Principal evaluation specialist (individual, international, 3 person-months, intermittent). 
Tasks will include the following: 
(i)  Provide overall project management for the midterm evaluation report, including 
status reporting to the ADB project officer; manage the national consultants; and 
communicate with government officials and other stakeholders as needed. 
(ii)  Review ADB documents related to the fund (i.e., Board papers, Independent 
Evaluation Department reports, if available). 
(iii)  Do  comparative  analysis  on  fund  management  procedures  with  other  ADB-
administered funds. 
(iv)  Perform desk reviews of fund annual reports, TA papers, and TA completion 
reports. 
(v)  Prepare case studies for at least 10 completed TA projects financed by the fund, 
with consideration of sector, region, TA type, and fund distribution. 
(vi)  Conduct  interviews  of  key  informants  and  stakeholders  including  relevant 
government officers, ADB staff, and consultants related to the case projects. 
(vii)  Prepare a draft evaluation report for circulation including a summary of the study, 
findings, and recommendations plus supporting annexes, as required on the use 
of the fund.  
(viii)  Propose streamlined fund administration procedures. 
(ix)  Incorporate inputs from the other international and national consultants into the 
final reports, ensuring consistency in structure and quality assurance. 
(x)  Liaise with and report to the ADB project officer.

(b)  The general part should include technology trends, policy and regulatory 
issues,  business  environment  conducive  for  the  private  sectors, 
development issues in rural areas, and case studies (at least five types of 
interventions).
